questions.question: Which of the following is a characteristic finding in the fundus examination of a patient with Stargardt disease?

options.B: Cotton wool spots and Hard exudates

questions.explanation: findings seen in Stargardt Disease Beaten bronze appearance on fundus examination Snail line appearance On FFA (Fundus fluorescein angiography) : Dark choroid/ silent choroid sign. Fig: of Stargardt Disease Stargardt Disease Most common juvenile macular dystrophy. Autosomal recessive It is a dystrophy of the RPE. It is a variant of Fundus flavi-maculatus. It is the most common macular dystrophy. The gene involved is STD most common, ABCA. Clinical features Symptoms: It manifests in the initial decades. There will be gradual diminishing of central vision. The vision drops to less than 6/60. There will be decreased color vision or impaired dark adaptation. Signs: Beaten bronze appearance Dark choroid/ silent choroid sign Normal FFA: background fluorescence d/t dye in choroidal vessels (Option B) Cotton wool spots and Hard exudates are seen in fundus examination of diabetic retinopathy patients (Option C) Dark choroid/ silent choroid sign is seen on Fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) (Option D) Honey-comb appearance is the characteristic finding in cystoid macular edema

questions.question: A 14-month-old child is diagnosed with retinoblastoma in the right eye. The tumor is confined to the retina, located posterior to equator, measures 2.5 mm in greatest dimension, and is located 3.5 mm from the fovea. There is no vitreous or subretinal seeding. According to the International Classification of Retinoblastoma (ICRB), how would this tumor be classified, and what will be the appropriate treatment?

options.A: Group A; Systemic chemotherapy with focal consolidation

questions.explanation: criteria of the International Classification of Retinoblastoma: Tumor confined to the retina Located posterior to the equator <3 mm in size >3 mm from the fovea and >1.5 mm from the optic disc No subretinal or vitreous seeding Laser photocoagulation is an appropriate focal treatment for small tumors like this in Group A . International Classification of Retinoblastoma (ICRB) Group Description Treatment Group A Small intraretinal tumors (<3 mm), away from foveola/optic disc, no seeding Focal therapy (laser photocoagulation, cryotherapy) Group B All remaining discrete tumors confined to retina, any size or location; no seeding Systemic chemotherapy ± focal therapy Group C Local subretinal/vitreous seeding, discrete Chemotherapy ± focal Group D Diffuse seeding Chemoreduction ± external beam radiation Group E Extensive tumor, neovascular glaucoma, opaque media, invasion Enucleation Group A; Systemic chemotherapy with focal consolidation (Option A): Incorrect. Group A tumors are treated with focal therapy only , not systemic chemotherapy. Group B; Plaque radiotherapy (Option B): Incorrect. This tumor does not qualify as Group B. Also, plaque radiotherapy is reserved for select recurrences or larger tumors not suitable for laser. Group B; Enucleation (Option C): Incorrect. Enucleation is not indicated in Group A or B unless there is treatment failure or vision is unsalvageable. Reference: pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5998397/

questions.question: A 2-year-old child is brought to the ophthalmology clinic with a white pupillary reflex in the right eye, noticed by the parents in flash photography. On examination, the child has strabismus. Which of the following is NOT a condition to be considered in the differential diagnosis of this presentation?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Optic nerve glioma Explanation: The case presented describes a classic presentation of retinoblastoma , for which optic nerve glioma is not a differential diagnosis . Optic nerve gliomas usually present with proptosis, visual loss, and optic nerve swelling , but not typically with leukocoria or an intraocular mass with calcification. Various conditions other than retinoblastoma, which present as leukocoria are collectively called pseudoglioma. Differential diagnosis of Retinoblastoma Leukocoria Congenital cataract Inflammatory deposits in vitreous following a plastic cyclitis or choroiditis, Coloboma of the choroid, Retinopathy of prematurity (Option C) Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (Option B) Toxocara endophthalmitis Exudative retinopathy of Coats (Option A) Endophytic retinoblastoma Tuberous sclerosis Neurofibromatosis Astrocytoma Exophytic Retinoblastoma Exudative retinopathy of Coats Reference: Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th Edition, Page 864, 865

questions.question: A 2-year-old child presents with leukocoria in the right eye. Fundus examination reveals a white, elevated mass in the retina. Histopathological examination of the tumor shows rosettes with central lumen. Which of the following is the most specific histological feature for this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes Explanation: The question describes a classic presentation of retinoblastoma , which is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in children. The key features pointing to this diagnosis are: Age of presentation: Retinoblastoma typically occurs in young children, usually before 5 years of age. Leukocoria: This is the most common presenting sign of retinoblastoma, often described as a white pupillary reflex. Fundus examination: A white, elevated mass in the retina is characteristic of retinoblastoma. Most specific histopathological feature of retinoblastoma is Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes , which are rosettes with a central lumen as shown in the diagram below. Diagnostic modalities for Retinoblastoma: Histopathology Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (highly specific)- These are composed of an ‘empty’ lumen surrounded by columnar cells Homer-Wright rosettes - These are pseudo-rosettes and consist of cells surrounding a central lumen made up of their processes Undifferentiated tumor cells Areas of necrosis and calcification Clinical Presentation Leukocoria (60%) Strabismus (20%) Painful red eye (7%) Poor vision (5%) Asymptomatic (3%) Fundus Examination White, elevated mass in the retina Can be endophytic, exophytic, or mixed growth Imaging CT scan: Calcification in 90% of cases MRI: Better for evaluating optic nerve and extraocular extension Ultrasound: Useful for initial screening Genetic Testing RB1 gene mutation on chromosome 13q14 Homer-Wright rosettes (Option A), Pseudorosettes (Option C), Undifferentiated tumor cells (Option D) are histological features seen in retinoblastoma, but are not highly specific.

questions.question: A 2-year-old child presents with the following findings as shown in the image. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the RB1 gene. Which of the following statements best describes the genetic findings associated with this condition? a 100% chance of passing on the mutation. somatic mutation. familial and sporadic cases.

options.A: Retinoblastoma can be inherited in an autosomal dominant manner, with affected individuals having
options.B: Retinoblastoma typically arises from a germline mutation in the RB1 gene, followed by a second
options.C: Affected children with retinoblastoma often have mutations in both the RB1 and TP53 genes.
options.D: A single mutation in the RB1 gene is usually sufficient for the development of retinoblastoma in both

questions.explanation: followed by a second somatic mutation. Correct Answer: B) Retinoblastoma typically arises from a germline mutation in the RB1 gene, followed by a second somatic mutation. Explanation: Retinoblastoma is typically caused by a germline mutation in the RB1 gene (inherited or de novo) followed by a second somatic mutation or "second hit" in the retina, leading to the development of the tumor. Retinoblastoma is caused by inactivation of both alleles of the RB1 tumor suppressor gene . There are two forms: Heritable (germline) : Seen in about 40% of cases, this form often results in bilateral retinoblastoma. It involves a germline mutation of the RB1 gene in all cells, followed by a somatic mutation in the retinal cells. They are prone to develop non-ocular tumors like osteosarcoma. Non-heritable (sporadic) : This form usually involves a unilateral tumor and arises from two somatic mutations that occur in the retinal cells after embryo formation, without a germline mutation. Cannot be passed to offspring and is not prone for developing non-ocular tumors. Knudson’s Two-Hit Hypothesis: This hypothesis explains the development of retinoblastoma . According to this model: In heritable retinoblastoma, the child inherits a germline mutation in one allele of the RB1 gene (the first hit). A subsequent somatic mutation in the other allele in the retinal cells (the second hit) leads to tumor formation. In sporadic cases, both alleles of the RB1 gene are inactivated by somatic mutations (both hits occurring postnatally). questions.question: A 55-year-old woman with a history of proliferative diabetic retinopathy presents with sudden vision changes in her right eye. She reports seeing floaters and flashes of light. On fundoscopy, there is evidence of fibrous tissue contraction and retinal elevation, but no retinal breaks are seen. What is the most appropriate treatment approach for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Pars plana vitrectomy Explanation: The patient’s symptoms and fundoscopy findings, including fibrous tissue contraction and retinal elevation without retinal breaks, are consistent with tractional retinal detachment . In this condition, the primary treatment approach is pars plana vitrectomy , which removes the vitreous and addresses the traction caused by the fibrous tissue, thereby relieving the retinal detachment. Clinical features: Presence of vitreoretinal bands associated with the underlying disease. Absence of retinal breaks. A concave, localized detachment that usually does not extend to the ora serrata. Maximum retinal elevation at sites of vitreoretinal traction. Severely reduced retinal mobility with no shifting fluid. Focal traction from cellular membranes can occasionally cause retinal tears, leading to a combined tractional-rhegmatogenous detachment. Treatment for tractional retinal detachment: Pars plana vitrectomy (PPV) is the standard approach for tractional retinal detachment. It involves removing cutting the vitreoretinal tractional bands and internal tamponade with either a long-acting gas or silicon oil. Treatment for exudative retinal detachment: Treatment focuses on managing the primary disease responsible for the exudative retinal detachment. Since exudative retinal detachment can be caused by transudate, exudate, or hemorrhage, fluid absorption results in the detachment resolving on its own. If the detachment is due to intraocular tumors, enucleation may be necessary. Laser photocoagulation (Option A) is used in proliferative retinopathies to prevent further neovascularization but does not address existing tractional detachment. Cryotherapy with scleral buckling (Option B) is effective in rhegmatogenous retinal detachment, not for tractional detachment. Pneumatic retinopexy (Option D) is not suitable for tractional or exudative detachments, as it primarily addresses rhegmatogenous detachment with retinal breaks.

questions.question: A 60-year-old man presents with a sudden onset of flashes of light and a shadow resembling a curtain in the peripheral vision of his right eye. He denies any recent trauma. On examination, fundus evaluation reveals a retinal detachment with a retinal break in the upper temporal quadrant. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

options.C: Pars plana vitrectomy with silicone oil tamponade
options.D: Drainage of subretinal fluid with diathermy to seal the break

questions.explanation: detachment with a small break in the upper quadrant. Pneumatic retinopexy is an appropriate choice for treating retinal detachments with small breaks in the superior retina. Treatment of Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment: The primary goals of treating rhegmatogenous retinal detachment are sealing retinal breaks, reducing vitreous traction, and flattening the retina by draining subretinal fluid (SRF) and providing external or internal tamponade. Sealing Retinal Breaks: All retinal breaks must be identified and sealed by inducing aseptic chorioretinitis. Techniques include cryocoagulation (for scleral buckling and pneumoretinopexy) or endo-laser photocoagulation (during vitrectomy). Drainage of Subretinal Fluid (SRF): SRF is carefully drained by inserting a fine needle through the sclera and choroid to allow fluid to escape, promoting retinal reattachment. In some cases, SRF drainage may not be necessary. Maintaining Chorioretinal Apposition: Scleral buckling: A surgical technique where material sutured onto the sclera (explant) creates an inward indentation (buckle). It is commonly used in simple cases by inserting a silicone band or sponge. Scleral buckling is an external retinal detachment surgery, which involves suturing an explant (material) onto the sclera to create an inward indentation (buckle). The buckle serves to close retinal breaks by pressing the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) against the sensory retina and reduces vitreoretinal traction. Urgent surgery is necessary for acute retinal detachment if the macula is not involved. Ideal for retinal detachment secondary to post-traumatic dialysis. Pneumatic retinopexy: (Option B) A minimally invasive quick and OP based procedure to reattach the retina. Uses an intravitreal gas bubble with cryotherapy or laser to seal retinal breaks. No scleral buckling is needed. Common gases: Sulfur hexafluoride (SF6) and perfluoropropane (C3F8). Used for uncomplicated retinal detachments. Ideal for small breaks or multiple breaks covering less than two clock hours in the upper peripheral retina. Vitrectomy and Internal Tamponade: Pars plana vitrectomy is performed for complicated or recurrent cases of RD and tractional detachments. This involves removing the vitreous, draining SRF, and flattening the retina using silicone oil or perfluorocarbon liquids. Endolaser photocoagulation is applied around breaks and retinotomy sites to create chorioretinal adhesions, followed by internal tamponade with gas (SF6 or C3F8) or silicone oil. Intravitreal

questions.question: A 55-year-old man reports the sudden appearance of flashes of light, followed by a dark cloud or veil in the peripheral vision of his left eye. Examination reveals a greyish reflex in the affected quadrant of the retina. What type of retinal detachment is most likely in this patient?
questions.explanation: separation of the neurosensory retina from the retinal pigment epithelium. Etiology: Age: most common in 40-60 years. Sex. More common in males (M:F - 3:2). Myopia. About 40% cases of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment are myopic. Aphakia and pseudophakia. Trauma. It may also act as a predisposing factor. Senile posterior vitreous detachment (PVD): It is associated with retinal detachment in many cases. Retinal degenerations predisposed to retinal detachment: Lattice degeneration, Snail track degeneration, Acquired or degenerative retinoschisis, and Focal pigment clumps. Retinal detachment can be classified into three types: Rhegmatogenous or primary retinal detachment Tractional retinal detachment Exudative retinal detachment Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment : This is the most common type and occurs due to a retinal tear or break, allowing subretinal fluid to enter and separate the sensory retina from the pigmentary epithelium. Tractional Retinal Detachment : Results from the pulling of the retina by fibrous or vascular tissue, commonly seen in fibrovascular proliferative conditions like diabetic retinopathy, without a retinal break. Exudative Retinal Detachment : Caused due to choroidal pathologies or by tumors pushing the retina or fluid accumulation under the retina due to inflammation or vascular abnormalities, without any associated retinal tear or traction. Type of Retinal Detachment Clinical Features Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment Floaters (dark spots) due to rapid vitreous degeneration. Photopsia (flashes of light) caused by retinal irritation from vitreous movements. Gradual visual field loss, initially localized, progressing to total vision loss as detachment spreads. Dark veil/cloud in front of the eye , particularly when detachment reaches the posterior region. Sudden, painless vision loss in large, central detachment. Retinal breaks may be round, horseshoe-shaped, slit-like, or large anterior dialysis. Vitreous pigments (tobacco dusting or Shaffer sign ) are seen in the anterior vitreous with posterior vitreous detachment. Old retinal detachment shows retinal thinning, subretinal demarcation lines (high water marks), and secondary intraretinal cysts. Tractional Retinal Detachment Gradual, progressive visual loss Typically painless No associated flashes or floaters Vitreoretinal bands present No retinal breaks Detached area - concave and localized No shifting fluid Exudative Retinal Detachment Painless and sudden or gradual visual loss No photopsia, holes/ tears, folds and undulations. Smooth and convex with pigmentary disturbances Rounded and fixed with neovascularization on the tumor summit.

questions.question: A 10-year-old child presents with a mild reduction in vision in both eyes. Fundus examination reveals a "sunny-side up egg" appearance in the macular region with yellowish subretinal material. The child’s father has a similar history of visual impairment since childhood. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: (BVMD) , also known as juvenile-onset vitelliform macular dystrophy, is the second most common macular dystrophy after Stargardt disease. Caused by mutations in the BEST1 gene located on chromosome 11q13. Bestrophin, the protein produced by this gene, functions as a transmembrane ion channel in the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE). Inherited in an autosomal dominant (AD) pattern. Usually begins in childhood Clinical Features : Stages of the disease include: Pre-vitelliform : abnormal EOG, normal fundus in asymptomatic patients. Vitelliform : a characteristic "egg yolk or sunny-side up" macular lesion. The lesions can vary in size and developmental stage between the two eyes. Pseudohypopyon: partially regressed lesion. Vitelliruptive : Lesion fragments, visual acuity declines - “scrambled egg appearance”. Atrophic : Pigment disappears, leading to RPE atrophy. Visual acuity - stable early on but declines in adulthood due to complications like choroidal neovascularization (CNV) , scarring, or geographic atrophy. Diagnosis : Fundus Autofluorescence (FAF) : hyper autofluorescence yellowish material. Fluorescein Angiography (FA) : hypofluorescence due to lesion masking. Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT) : hyperreflective material beneath and within the RPE. Electro-oculography (EOG) : Severely subnormal across all stages (Arden index <1.5). Hallmark- normal electroretinogram (ERG) but abnormal electrooculogram (EOG). Stargardt Disease (Option A): Causes central vision loss with a characteristic "beaten-bronze" appearance and yellow flecks but is not associated with the vitelliform lesion. Retinitis Pigmentosa (Option C): Characterized by night blindness and peripheral vision loss, not macular lesions. Leber Congenital Amaurosis (Option D): A severe form of retinal dystrophy with early-onset blindness but lacks the specific macular changes seen in BVMD.

questions.question: A 16-year-old patient presents with progressive vision loss. On examination, the ophthalmologist notes a central scotoma and yellowish-white flecks in the macular region of the retina. A diagnosis of Stargardt disease is made. All of the following are true statements about Stargardt disease, except:

options.A: It is also known as juvenile macular dystrophy
options.C: Vitamin A supplementation should be avoided

questions.explanation: examination showing flame-shaped hemorrhages is seen in hypertensive retinopathy. All other options are true regarding Stargardt disease. Stargardt disease, also known as juvenile macular dystrophy, is the most common macular dystrophy. (Option A) Investigations: FFA: A dye is injected, and there is a dark background choroid fluorescence due to dense deposition of lipofuscin on retinal pigment epithelium. Since there's no choroidal background fluorescence seen, it is called "dark choroid syndrome" or "silent choroid syndrome". Fundus autofluorescence: No dye is seen, and all lipofuscin deposits are shining. (Option D) EOG abnormality. ERG: Late stages may affect the ERG, mainly photopic ERG abnormality. Treatment Avoid bright sunlight. Use sunglasses Avoid vitamin A, as it promotes lipofuscinosis. (Option C) Reference: AK Khurana Comprehensive Ophthalmology, 7th Edition, Pg.283, 301

questions.question: A 35-year-old male presents with sudden distrubunce of vision in his right eye for two weeks. He reports distortion of images. He has been intermittently using corticosteroids for allergies. His Visual acuity in the right eye is 6/18. FFA and OCT findings are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is not related to retinitis pigmentosa?
questions.explanation: deafness- Usher syndrome Systemic associations in Retinitis Pigmentosa Refsum's disease: It is a defect in the phytanic acid metabolism. RP+ Cerebellar ataxia+ Polyneuropathy. It is managed with a low phytanic acid diet. (Option A) Laurence-Moon-Bardet-Biedl syndrome (m/c): involves RP, mental retardation, obesity, polydactyly, and paraplegia. (Option B) Usher's syndrome: It is retinitis pigmentosa (RP) with Sensory neural deafness. Kearns-Sayer syndrome: involves RP, heart block, and chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia (CPEO). (Option C) Bassen-Kornzweig syndrome involves RP, acanthocytosis, abetalipoproteinemia, and ataxia. It is managed with a low-fat diet and vitamin supplements. Ocular associations in Retinitis Pigmentosa Keratoconus Posterior subcapsular cataract (PSC) Open-angle glaucoma (OAG) Cystoid macular edema (CME) Reference: AK Khurana Comprehensive Ophthalmology, 7th Edition, Pg.297, 298

questions.question: A 30-year-old woman presents with progressive night blindness and gradual loss of peripheral vision over the past few years. Her family history reveals that her father had similar symptoms. On examination, you observe characteristic retinal changes, including bone spicule pigmentation. To evaluate the functional status of her retina more accurately, which diagnostic test would you choose to confirm the suspicion of retinitis pigmentosa (RP)?
questions.explanation: pigmentosa that shows reduced scotopic, subnormal responses in early disease and becomes completely extinguished in advanced disease. Investigation of Retinitis Pigmentosa Electroretinography (ERG) is the investigation of choice - reduced scotopic rod in early disease and reduced photopic with progression. (Option A) EOG - subnormal - absence of light rise. (Option D) Perimetry: initially small mid-peripheral scotomas which gradually merge and may progress, leaving only a small island of residual central vision. Electroretinography (ERG): There's a decreased amplitude of both "a" and "b" waves. OCT - to identify cystoid macular edema (CME). (Option B) Dark adaptometry: Dark adaptation time is prolonged. Decreased Arden ratio may be present. Treatment of Retinitis Pigmentosa: The treatable RP includes Refsum's disease and Bassen-Kornzweig syndrome. The treatment includes- Regular follow-ups: Annual check-ups help detect complications, provide support, and track new treatment options. Low-vision aids: Includes devices, rehabilitation, and access to social services. Avoid smoking. Light protection: Outdoor sunglasses blocking wavelengths up to 550 nm with side protection. Indoors, amber lenses blocking 511–527 nm may enhance contrast sensitivity. Treatment for CMO: Oral acetazolamide or topical carbonic anhydrase inhibitors may reduce cystoid macular edema. Vitamin A: High-dose vitamin A (15,000 units/day) provides marginal benefits but should be used with caution due to risks like liver toxicity and increased lung cancer risk in smokers. Avoid during pregnancy. Lutein, possibly with zeaxanthin, is a safer alternative. A retinal implant (ARGUS-II) can also be performed. Low-vision aids (LVA) can also be used. It can also lead to cone dystrophy. Visual field testing (Option C) is important for evaluating the extent of vision loss, especially in RP where peripheral vision is often affected. However, it does not directly assess the functional status of the retinal photoreceptors.

questions.question: A 32-year-old female presents with difficulty seeing in low light and peripheral vision loss that has gradually worsened over several years. On fundoscopy, the following findings are noted. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Retinitis Pigmentosa Explanation: The image given above is retinitis pigmentosa fundoscopy findings showing a pale waxy disc, bony spicules, and attenuation of arteries. The Triad of retinitis pigmentosa includes a pale waxy disc due to consecutive optic atrophy, attenuation of arteries, and pigmentation disturbance in the form of bony spicules. Retinitis pigmentosa is a dystrophy of rods and cones, initially, rods are affected. Most common hereditary fundus dystrophy. It can be sporadic (40-50%) or hereditary. If hereditary, autosomal dominant is the most common mode of inheritance followed by autosomal recessive (AR). X-linked recessive inheritance is the least severe form. Clinical features: Symptoms: Nyctalopia (night blindness) Peripheral visual field loss Mid-peripheral superior scotoma leads to ring/ doughnut scotoma resulting in tubular/ tunnel vision Signs: Triad of a p ale waxy disc due to consecutive optic atrophy, attenuation of arteries , and pigmentation

questions.question: A 32-year-old woman presents with gradual central vision loss in both eyes. Fundus examination reveals concentric rings of retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) atrophy and hyperpigmentation centred on the fovea, creating a characteristic appearance. The image showing the appearance is given below: Which of the following is LEAST likely to be associated with this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Chronic central serous chorioretinopathy Explanation: The image shows the characteristic appearance of Bull's eye maculopathy , a retinal disorder characterised by concentric rings of RPE atrophy and hyperpigmentation centred on the fovea , creating an appearance resembling a bull's eye target. While chronic central serous chorioretinopathy can cause retinal pigment epithelium changes, it typically does not present with the characteristic bull's eye maculopathy appearance. Etiological causes of bull’s eye maculopathy

questions.question: A 68-year-old woman presents with gradual vision loss in her right eye over the past 6 months. Her ophthalmologist suspects age-related macular degeneration (AMD) and orders further tests. What is the most sensitive modality to detect exudative AMD?

options.B: Slit-lamp biomicroscopy using a +90 or +78 D lens

questions.explanation: most sensitive modality for detecting exudative (wet) AMD. Dry AMD Wet AMD Diagnostic Methods Slit-lamp biomicroscopy using a +90 or +78 D lens (Clinical diagnosis) Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT): outer retinal tubulation is seen in the outer nuclear layer. Fundus autofluorescence Amsler grid test Slit-lamp biomicroscopy using a +90 or +78 D lens Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT) (Most sensitive): RPE detachment is seen. Fluorescein angiography Indocyanine green angiography Treatment Options AREDS supplements (vitamins C, E, zinc, copper, lutein, zeaxanthin) Lifestyle modifications (smoking cessation, healthy diet) Regular monitoring to prevent progression to advanced disease Intravitreal anti-VEGF injections (e.g., bevacizumab, ranibizumab, aflibercept) Photodynamic therapy (in select cases) Rarely, laser photocoagulation (for extrafoveal CNV)

questions.question: A 72-year-old man presents with gradual vision loss in both eyes over the past year. His ophthalmologist diagnoses him with age-related macular degeneration (AMD). Which of the following statements about AMD is correct?

options.A: AMD is a hereditary degeneration exclusively affecting the macula
options.B: Wet AMD accounts for 90% of all AMD cases but only 10% of severe vision loss
options.C: Dry AMD is characterised by choroidal neovascularisation
options.D: AMD is the most common cause of permanent central visual loss after 6th decade

questions.explanation: decade Correct Answer: D) AMD is the most common cause of permanent central visual loss after 6th decade Explanation: Age-related Macular Degeneration (AMD) is a nonhereditary degeneration involving the choriocapillaris, Bruch's membrane, retinal pigment epithelium, and photoreceptors. It is indeed the most common cause of permanent central visual loss after 6th decade. Based on the clinical findings of macular degeneration, It is of 2 types : Exudative (wet) Non-exudative (dry) Category Dry AMD Wet AMD Definition Nonexudative macular degeneration Exudative macular degeneration Prevalence 90% of all AMD cases 10% of all AMD cases Vision Loss Accounts for about 10% of legal blindness in AMD Major blinding form, accounts for 90% of severe vision loss in AMD Key Features Drusen, RPE abnormalities, geographic atrophy Choroidal neovascularization (CNV), subretinal fluid Pathophysiology Accumulation of drusen, dysfunction of RPE Growth of new blood vessels from choroid, leakage of fluid Progression Generally slow Can be rapid DRY AMD: (Option A) AMD is a nonhereditary degeneration primarily affecting the macula involving the choriocapillaris, Bruch's membrane, retinal pigment epithelium, and photoreceptors. (Option B) Wet AMD accounts for only 10% of all AMD cases but is responsible for 90% of severe vision loss in AMD patients. (Option C) Choroidal neovascularization is a characteristic of wet AMD, not dry AMD. Dry AMD is characterized by drusen, RPE abnormalities, and geographic atrophy.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about angioid streaks is incorrect?

options.A: They represent breaks in Bruch's membrane
options.B: They are commonly associated with sickle cell anemia
options.C: Choroidal neovascularization (CNV) frequently develops in these patients
options.D: Steroids are primarily used for the prevention of CNV

questions.explanation: crack-like dehiscences in Bruch's membrane, appearing as irregular reddish-brown or gray lines radiating from the optic disc. Bruch's membrane: The innermost layer of the choroid is the Bruch's membrane. It is a membrane between the choroid and the retinal pigment epithelium. It lines the layer of choriocapillaris. Asymptomatic angioid streaks do not require treatment. However, anti-VEGF therapy can be used to prevent choroidal neovascularization. Angioid Streaks: Definition Crack-like dehiscences in Bruch's membrane, appearing as reddish-brown or gray lines radiating from the optic disc (Option A) Association with conditions Pseudoxanthoma elasticum (PXE) - Most common Ehlers-Danlos syndrome Paget's disease Sickle cell disease (Option B) Complication Choroidal neovascularization (CNV) frequently develops in affected patients (Option C) Treatment Anti-VEGF therapy for choroidal neovascularization Reference: Yanoff and Duker Ophthalmology Edition 5th Pg. 603, 604 www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK538151/

questions.question: A 28-year-old woman with a history of high myopia since childhood presents for a routine eye examination. She reports occasional floaters and difficulty seeing at night. On fundus examination, the ophthalmologist notes a tilted optic disc, peripapillary atrophy, and a myopic crescent. Which of the following is NOT typically associated with the condition?
questions.explanation: with pathological myopia . Pathological myopia is a progressive form of myopia characterized by excessive axial elongation of the eyeball and degenerative changes in the retina and choroid. The optic disc in pathological myopia often appears large and pale due to the stretching of the eye, but it is not edematous. Pathological Myopia Definition Pathological/degenerative/progressive myopia is a rapidly progressive error that starts in childhood at 5-10 years of age and results in high myopia (>-6D) during early adult life. Etiology Rapid axial growth of the eyeball outside normal biological variations Genetic factors (major role) More common in women than men Autosomal dominant pathological myopia Heredity- Familial, more common in women and in certain races Autosomal Dominant - linked to genes 18p11.31 and 12q21-23 Sex-linked recessive - high myopia (>6D) General growth process (minor role) nutritional deficiency endocrine disturbances Symptoms Defective vision with considerable failure in visual function Muscae volitantes (floaters) Difficulty in night vision in very high myopes with degenerative changes Signs Prominent eyeballs, often appear elongated Exophthalmos, especially in unilateral cases Cornea is large The anterior chamber is deep Pupils are slightly large and react sluggishly to light Fundus examination reveals: The optic disc appears large and pale Characteristic myopic crescent Tigroid fundus Myopic crescent (temporal to disc margin) Complications Retinal detachment Complicated cataract Choroidal hemorrhage and neovascularization Vitreous hemorrhage Primary open-angle glaucoma (associated condition) Degenerative changes in the retina and choroid: Chorioretinal atrophy at the macula Foster-Fuchs spots (Option A) Lattice degeneration (Option B) Total retinal atrophy Posterior staphyloma (Option C) Degenerative changes in vitreous: Liquefaction Vitreous opacities Posterior vitreous detachment

questions.question: A 65-year-old presents with visual blurring in the left eye, 20/40 vision, and a history of cataract surgery three months ago. Fundus examination shows retinal thickening and a dull foveal reflex. OCT and FFA findings are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
